attributes.title: Outcome of T-cell activating immunotherapy in mismatch repair deficient tumors and the predictive value of tumor-induced immune evasion mechanisms: a scoping review protocol
attributes.description:
Review title and time scale
Title
Outcome of T-cell activating immunotherapy in mismatch repair deficient tumors and the predictive value of tumor-induced immune evasion mechanisms: a scoping review.

Anticipated start date 
01/03 2020

Anticipated completion date
01/01 2021

Stage of review at the time of submission
The search string for the review has been tested and approved on March 20, 2020. Review of title and abstracts of the identified articles are ongoing. Data extraction has not yet started. 

Review team details
Contact person: 
Name:
Maria Rasmussen
Email
Maria.Rasmussen.07@regionh.dk
Phone number
+4538627700
Organization
Danish HNPCC Register, Clinical Research Centre, Copenhagen University Hospital, Denmark. 
Working address
Kettegård Allé 30, 2650 Hvidovre, Denmark

Authors
Ms Maria Rasmussen1, Dr. Jon Durhuus1, Prof. Ove Andersen1, Prof. Mef Nilbert1,2,3, Dr. Christina Therkildsen1. 
1Clinical Research Centre, Copenhagen University Hospital, Denmark
2The Danish Cancer Society Research Center, Copenhagen, Denmark
3Department of Clinical Sciences, Division of Oncology, Lund University, Lund, Sweden

Funding
Danish Cancer Research Society (Knæk cancer fonden), R246-A14570.

Conflicts of interest
The authors have no conflicts of interest to declare.

Review methods
Rationale (optional)
Checkpoint immunotherapy is administered based on disruption of tumor cell-induced inhibition of cytotoxic T cell mediated apoptosis. T cell re-activation is currently effectuated through the FDA and EMA approved drugs Ipilimumab, Atezolizumab, Avelumab, Pembrolizumab, Durvalumab, and Nivolumab, which target the PD1/PD-L1 or CTLA-4/B7.1/2 inhibitory mechanisms. These treatment strategies are tested in various organs, combinations, and lines of treatment. The drugs are highly efficient in patients with tumors that have a high mutation burden, mismatch repair deficiency/microsatellite instability, and high levels of tumor-infiltrating T cells, which are hallmarks of the hereditary cancer syndrome, Lynch syndrome. Though inclusion in clinical studies is based on patients having this tumor phenotype, up against 50% does not respond and predictive biomarkers are currently investigated to increase the response rates. 

Review questions
This scoping review aims to: 
1)	Systematically map current knowledge and gaps in the literature on the outcome from the FDA and EMA approved T-cell activating drugs Ipilimumab, Pembrolizumab, Atezolizumab, Avelumab, Durvalumab, and Nivolumab in patients with mismatch repair deficient/microsatellite instable tumors? How is this outcome affected by tumor-induced immune evasion mechanisms?
2)	Systematically map current knowledge and gaps in what is known in the literature on the outcome from the FDA and EMA approved T-cell activating drugs Ipilimumab, Pembrolizumab, Atezolizumab, Nivolumab in Lynch syndrome patients? How is this outcome affected by tumor-induced immune evasion mechanisms?

Literature search 
Literature will be searched at the following electronic bibliographic databases: PubMed, EMBASE, and the Cochrane Library by an experienced librarian. The search string was assembled from MeSH and non-MeSH terms included in the three categories: [cancer] AND [Lynch syndrome/MSI/MMR-deficiency] AND [approved T-cell activating checkpoint inhibitors]: 
((((((((Neoplasms[MeSH Terms]) OR (Neoplas*[Text Word])) OR (Tumor*[Text Word])) OR (Tumour*[Text Word])) OR (Cancer*[Text Word])) OR (Malignan*[Text Word])) OR (Carcinoma*[Text Word])) 
AND 
(((((((((((((((((((("Colorectal Neoplasms, Hereditary Nonpolyposis"[Mesh]) OR ("Lynch syndrome"[Text Word])) OR (HNPCC[Text Word])) OR (“Hereditary Nonpolyposis”[Text Word])) OR (“Hereditary Non polyposis”[Text Word])) OR (“Familial Nonpolyposis”[Text Word])) OR (“Familial Non polyposis”[Text Word])) OR (“DNA Mismatch Repair"[MeSH Terms])) OR (“Mismatch Repair”[Text Word])) OR (“DNA Mismatch”[Text Word])) OR (MMR[Text Word])) OR (dMMR[Text Word])) OR (d-MMR[Text Word])) OR (MMR-d[Text Word])) OR (MMRd[Text Word])) OR ("Microsatellite Instability"[MeSH Terms])) OR ("Replication Error Phenotype*"[Text Word])) OR (MSI[Text Word])) OR ("Microsatellite Instability"[Text Word])) OR ("Microsatellite unstable"[Text Word]))) 
AND 
((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((((("Ipilimumab"[MeSH Terms]) OR (Ipilimumab[Text Word])) OR (Yervoy[Text Word])) OR (MDX010[Text Word])) OR (MDX-010[Text Word])) OR (MDX101[Text Word])) OR (MDX-101[Text Word])) OR (BMS734016[Text Word])) OR (BMS-734016[Text Word])) OR (Strentarga[Text Word])) OR ("CTLA-4 Antigen"[MeSH Terms])) OR (CTLA4[Text Word])) OR (CTLA-4[Text Word])) OR (CD152[Text Word])) OR ("Cytotoxic T-Lymphocyte-Associated Antigen 4"[Text Word])) OR ("Cytotoxic T Lymphocyte Antigen 4"[Text Word])) OR ("Programmed Cell Death 1 Receptor"[MeSH Terms])) OR (“Programmed Cell Death"[Text Word])) OR (“Programmed Death"[Text Word])) OR (PD-1[Text Word])) OR (PD1[Text Word])) OR (CD279[Text Word])) OR ("B7-H1 Antigen"[MeSH Terms])) OR (PD-L1[Text Word])) OR (PDL1[Text Word])) OR (PDL-1[Text Word])) OR (B7-H1[Text Word])) OR (B7H1[Text Word])) OR (CD274[Text Word])) OR ("B7 homolog 1"[Text Word])) OR ("B7 homologue 1"[Text Word])) OR (PDCD1[Text Word])) OR (PDCD1LG1[Text Word])) OR ("pembrolizumab"[Supplementary Concept])) OR (Pembrolizumab[Text Word])) OR (SCH-900475[Text Word])) OR (SCH900475[Text Word])) OR (Keytruda[Text Word])) OR (MK-3475[Text Word])) OR (MK3475[Text Word])) OR (Lambrolizumab[Text Word])) OR ("Nivolumab"[MeSH Terms])) OR (Nivolumab[Text Word])) OR (Opdivo[Text Word])) OR (ONO-4538[Text Word])) OR (ONO4538[Text Word])) OR (MDX-1106[Text Word])) OR (MDX1106[Text Word])) OR (BMS-936558[Text Word])) OR (BMS936558[Text Word])) OR (Cmab819[Text Word])) OR (Cmab-819[Text Word])) OR ("atezolizumab"[Supplementary Concept])) OR (Atezolizumab[Text Word])) OR (MPDL3280A[Text Word])) OR (MPDL-3280A[Text Word])) OR (Tecentriq[Text Word])) OR (Tecntriq[Text Word])) OR (RG7446[Text Word])) OR (RG-7446[Text Word])) OR ("durvalumab"[Supplementary Concept])) OR (durvalumab[Text Word])) OR (MEDI4736[Text Word])) OR (MEDI-4736[Text Word])) OR (Imfinzi[Text Word]))

We will also scan the reference list of all relevant reviews and original articles in order to avoid selection bias.

URL to search strategy
Not applicable

Condition or domain being studied
Patients with mismatch repair deficient/microsatellite instable tumors treated with the FDA and EMA approved T-cell activating drugs Ipilimumab, Pembrolizumab, Avelumab, Atezolizumab, Durvalumab, and Nivolumab.

Participants/Population
All patients regardless of age have been pre-selected based on tumor phenotype showing microsatellite instability or mismatch repair deficiency through immunohistochemical loss of protein expression of the mismatch proteins MLH1, MSH2, MSH6 or PMS2. There are no selection criteria regarding tumor type. 

Concept
All patients have been treated with the FDA and EMA approved T cell activating drugs Ipilimumab, Pembrolizumab, Avelumab, Atezolizumab, Durvalumab, or Nivolumab and tumor progression or regression (scored according to the RECIST criteria) and/or overall/progression-free survival have been collected in a medical setting. For some studies, biomarkers may have been investigated retrospectively to determine their predictive value. 

Context
All periods of time and duration of follow-up before March 20, 2020, are eligible. 

Primary outcomes (optional)
Primary outcomes include: objective response rate, overall survival, progression-free survival, progressive disease, resistance and biomarker analyses (protein analyses, gene expression analyses or DNA mutation analyses) on immune response and immune evasion pathways. 

Secondary outcomes (optional)
Secondary outcomes include: all of the primary outcomes described above but specifically in Lynch syndrome patients.

Data extraction
The full set of titles and abstracts retrieved will be independently screened for eligibility by three authors (Maria Rasmussen and Christina Therkildsen) and the level of agreement will be discussed. A pilot search has been conducted to study the selection criteria and compare articles identified in the beginning and end of the screening process. A third reviewer (Jon Durhuus) will be consulted where agreement cannot be achieved. 
A standardized data extraction formula will be developed and pilot-tested among all reviewers. Data extraction will include: tumor type (e.g. location, organ, level of mismatch repair deficiency, level of microsatellite instability), treatment regimen (e.g. pharmaceutical drug used, line of treatment, combinational treatment, period), outcome (e.g. objective response rate, overall survival, progression-free survival, resistance), and biomarkers (e.g. name of the protein/genes, type of analyses, level of expression, percentage of positive tumors).  All studies need to be on homo sapiens and written in English. Conference abstracts will be screened, but only included if all requested data are available.

Risk of quality assessment
Since this is a scoping review, quality assessment will not be conducted.

Strategy of synthesis
The synthesis will focus on providing: 1) mapping the outcomes from checkpoint-based immunotherapy in patients with mismatch repair deficient/microsatellite instable tumors and 2) describe the predictive value of immune response and immune evasion-related possible up-coming biomarkers associated with tumor-induced immune evasion mechanisms.

Review general information
Type of review
Scoping review

Language
English

Country
Denmark

Dissemination plans
Results will be published in a peer-reviewed journal.

Keywords
Immunotherapy, mismatch repair deficient cancer, microsatellite instability, scoping review, predictive biomarkers

Current review status
Ongoing (reviewing title and abstract)

summary.value:
Checkpoint immunotherapy is administered based on disruption of tumor cell-induced inhibition of cytotoxic T cell mediated apoptosis. T cell re-activation is currently effectuated through the FDA and EMA approved drugs Ipilimumab, Atezolizumab, Avelumab, Pembrolizumab, Durvalumab, and Nivolumab, which target the PD1/PD-L1 or CTLA-4/B7.1/2 inhibitory mechanisms. These treatment strategies are tested in various organs, combinations, and lines of treatment. The drugs are highly efficient in patients with tumors that have a high mutation burden, mismatch repair deficiency/microsatellite instability, and high levels of tumor-infiltrating T cells, which are hallmarks of the hereditary cancer syndrome, Lynch syndrome. Though inclusion in clinical studies is based on patients having this tumor phenotype, up against 50% does not respond and predictive biomarkers are currently investigated to increase the response rates. 

We aim to systematically map current knowledge and gaps in the literature on the outcome from the FDA and EMA approved T-cell activating drugs Ipilimumab, Pembrolizumab, Atezolizumab, Avelumab, Durvalumab, and Nivolumab in patients with mismatch repair deficient/microsatellite instable tumors (in particular, Lynch syndrome)? How is this outcome affected by tumor-induced immune evasion mechanisms? 

Metaanalyses have been conducted on specific biomarkers in specific tumor types but these has been based on location and organs affected. Furthermore, these reviews have only included sporadic cancers. As Lynch syndrome is a multi-tumor syndrome with development of predominantly mismatch repair deficient/microsatellite instable tumor types, and as drugs like Pembrolizumab has been approved as a pan-cancer drug for microsatellite instable tumors, we wish to review the outcome of similar drugs in all mismatch repair deficient/microsatellite instable tumors, disregarding the location. No review has been done for Lynch syndrome cancers and/or microsatellite instable cancers.

attributes.title: General Risk Attitudes and COVID-19
attributes.description:
The COVID-19 pandemic may snowball into becoming a mental-health pandemic (Holmes et al., 2020, Lancet Psychiatry). Who is at risk of developing mental-health issues during the pandemic? Results from data-collection in a recent COVID-19 related project, aiming to delineate the role of general risk attitudes in shaping perceptions of the pandemic (and vice versa – see preregistration protocol: https://osf.io/cexyu), showed that people with a general disposition towards being risk averse exhibited more COVID-19 related anxiety. The predictive power of general risk attitude (GRA) in predicting COVID-19 related anxiety was much stronger than for age, income, and, educational level. It also was independent of gender (which also showed strong predictive power), domain-specific risk attitudes, frequency measures of everyday risk taking, and general decision-making skill (measures for which there was no predictive power). 
This is concerning because risk aversion and trait anxiety can together propel behavior such as panic buying, avoidance behavior leading to overly limited socialization, and self-medication. Moreover, being risk averse is a common trait, and the results thus hints the concerning possibility that many individuals in the general population may develop mental-health problems that are not easily fixed by providing safety nets (e.g., proper health care health risk-groups and economic risk-groups, since the anxiousness may be situated in a more dispositional manner.
The present study will examine the effect of GRA in greater detail, delineating possible mediators and moderators.

q2.value:
1.	Test if the finding that GRA predict COVID-Anxiety can be replicated (Bayesian factorial regression with COVID-Anxiety derived from best items from measures 8 and 9 as the dependent variable and GRA (derived from measure 6) as covariate. H0: Do not replicate. H1: Replicate. 
Also test if the predictive power can be increased through Boosted Regression. 

2.	Test if GRA also predict frequency measures of behavior (scores from items on measure 10 are tested on EFA, PCA, and item-rest correlations to derive an aggregate score ): H0: Attitudes do not carry over into measurable behaviors. H1: Attitudes carry over into measurable behaviors

3.	Test if the effect in point 1 withstands after controlling for Anxiety and Depression (i.e., using measures 12 and 13) as nuisance variables in the null-model. H1: GRA only have predictive power as part of the trait-anxiety concept, H2: GRA have unique predictive power

4.	Testing moderating and mediating role of variables (exploratory)(using factorial regressions and SEM-analyses):
- Beliefs (measure 7) H0: No effect, H1: Will reduce or amplify the effect
- Number of people who are affected in the city of residence H0: No effect, H1: Will reduce or amplify the effect
- COVID-19 experiences (measure 11) H0: No effect, H1: Will amplify or reduce the effect
- Anxiety (measure 12) H0: No effect,  H1: Will amplify or reduce the effect
- Depression (measure 13) H0: No effect, H1: Will amplify or reduce the effect

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
The e following data (in the order of presentation provided below) will be collected on MTurk (US residents):

Demographics
1. Age (same as in previous study)
2. Gender (same as in previous study)
3. Income (same as in previous study)
4. Educational level (same as in previous study)
5. City of residence
Risk Measure
6. General Risk Propensity Scale (GRiPS: Zhang et al., 2019)
COVID-19 Measures
7. Belief-related items (rephrased from items with satisfactory psychometric qualities on the previous study): 
a) I believe the corona virus will affect my own health 
b) I believe the corona virus will affect other people's health
c) I believe the pandemic will lead to economic losses for myself
d) I believe pandemic will lead to economic losses for others

8. Worry-related items (rephrased from items with satisfactory psychometric qualities on the previous study):
a) I am really concerned that the corona virus will affect my own health 
b) I am really concerned that the corona virus will affect other people's health
c)  I am really concerned that the effects of the corona virus will lead to economic losses for myself
d) I am really concerned that the effects of the corona virus will lead to economic losses for others
9. The Fear of COVID-19 scale (Ahorsu et al., 2020): 7 items in total. 
10. Frequency measures of COVID-19 related behavior (from Roy et al., 2020) on 4-point Likert scale (never, occasionally, sometimes, very often):
a) In the last week, how often have you avoided partying
b) In the last week, how often have you avoided social contact 
c) In the last week, how often have you avoided large meetings or gatherings?
d) In the last week, how often have you avoided ordering food online?
e) In the last week, how often have you had difficulty sleeping by being worried about the Coronavirus pandemic?
f) From the last week, how often do you feel the need to buy and stock all essentials at home?
g) From the last week, how often do you feel the need to use sanitizer or gloves?
h) From the last week, how often do you feel the need to wash your hands?
11. COVID-19 experiences
a) Have you been affected by the virus, and if so how sick did you get?
i) Have not been sick, ii) Mild symtoms, iii) Severe symtoms but not hospitalized, iv) Severe symtoms and hospitalized

b) How many people do you personally know that have got severely ill due to the coronavirus? 
c) How many people do you personally know that have died from coronavirus? 
d) How many people do you personally know that have suffered severely financially as a result of the pandemic? 
•	e) Are you working as a health-care professional? 
f) Are you included in any of the government-mentioned risk groups (asthma, chronic lung disease, diabetes, serious heart conditions, chronic kidney disease, severe obesity, aged 65 years or older, immunocompromised, liver disease, resident of long-term care facility). 
General Anxiety and Depression Measures
12. PROMIS-Anxiety Short Form (8 items)
13. PROMIS-Depression Short Form (8 items)

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
550 participants (previous studies have shown that 10% attrition rate is to be expected, leaving approx. 500 responses: more than double that of the previous study which relied on Bayesian statistics and showed that already 250 pps was enough for statistical power – the increase here is because more responses should lead to even more stable parameter estimates

The research and the consent procedure were approved by the ethic committee of Uppsala University. All participants received written information on the nature of survey, which did not involve deception, part-taking was voluntary, and participants were explicitly told that they could abort the study whenever they wished. In addition, no personal information was recorded in a way that could make identification of a specific participant possible. At the end, participants were also informed about measures that they could take if they, or someone they know, experience mental-health issue: “If you or someone you know is in crisis, please call 911, go to the nearest emergency room, call 1-800-273-TALK (8255) to reach a 24-hour crisis center, or text MHA to 741741 at the Crisis Text Line. You can also call 1-800-985-5990 or text “TalkWithUs” to 66746 at the SAMHSA Disaster Distress Helpline. Trained crisis workers will listen to you and direct you to the resources you need.” Participants received a wage of 1 U.S. Dollars for participation (in line with the general suggestion that participants should receive about 10 cents for each minute of participation: Chandler & Shapiro, 2016).

q12.value: Previous studies have shown that 10% attrition rate is to be expected, leaving approx. 500 responses: more than double that of the previous study which relied on Bayesian statistics and showed that already 250 pps was enough for statistical power – the increase here is because more responses should lead to even more stable parameter estimates

12. PROMIS-Anxiety Short Form (8 items)
13. PROMIS-Depression Short Form (8 items)
registration_responses.q10.question:
550 participants (previous studies have shown that 10% attrition rate is to be expected, leaving approx. 500 responses: more than double that of the previous study which relied on Bayesian statistics and showed that already 250 pps was enough for statistical power – the increase here is because more responses should lead to even more stable parameter estimates

The research and the consent procedure were approved by the ethic committee of Uppsala University. All participants received written information on the nature of survey, which did not involve deception, part-taking was voluntary, and participants were explicitly told that they could abort the study whenever they wished. In addition, no personal information was recorded in a way that could make identification of a specific participant possible. At the end, participants were also informed about measures that they could take if they, or someone they know, experience mental-health issue: “If you or someone you know is in crisis, please call 911, go to the nearest emergency room, call 1-800-273-TALK (8255) to reach a 24-hour crisis center, or text MHA to 741741 at the Crisis Text Line. You can also call 1-800-985-5990 or text “TalkWithUs” to 66746 at the SAMHSA Disaster Distress Helpline. Trained crisis workers will listen to you and direct you to the resources you need.” Participants received a wage of 1 U.S. Dollars for participation (in line with the general suggestion that participants should receive about 10 cents for each minute of participation: Chandler & Shapiro, 2016).

10. Frequency measures of COVID-19 related behavior (from Roy et al., 2020) on 4-point Likert scale (never, occasionally, sometimes, very often). - deduced to one aggregate score if possible. 
a) In the last week, how often have you avoided partying
b) In the last week, how often have you avoided social contact 
c) In the last week, how often have you avoided large meetings or gatherings?
d) In the last week, how often have you avoided ordering food online?

a) Have you been affected by the virus, and if so how sick did you get?
i) Have not been sick, ii) Mild symtoms, iii) Severe symtoms but not hospitalized, iv) Severe symtoms and hospitalized

attributes.title: Silhouette Database
attributes.description: Endeavour to create a Cross-Cultural Bicolour Affective Silhouette & Shape (BASS) Database

summary.value:
Online Study for English-speakers

1. Aim
Our aim is to create a normed database of Bicolor Affective Silhouettes & Shapes (BASS). For this, 583 black-on-white silhouette images will be rated for valence and arousal by English speakers.

2. Methods 

2.1 Material
We collected a total of 620 silhouettes. Most silhouettes were acquired through internet search using Google Images (images.google.com) under the creative commons license, searching either directly for silhouettes or images that we edited into black-white-silhouettes using GIMP. 

We restricted our image search to images labelled “available for reuse with modification”.
The sources of the silhouettes are most notably Pixabay (pixabay.com; n = 477), CleanPNG (cleanpng.com; n = 34), and svgsilh (svgsilh.com; n = 32). Twenty silhouettes were created for this project by a graphic designer. We collected a wide range of images, depicting persons, animals, objects, and scenes, which we indicate in a category column in the database for easier stimulus selection. Special focus was put on collecting images of a wide range of valence (positive, negative, and neutral) as well as arousal (low, medium, and high). Every image was scaled and/or cropped to a size of 300 x 300 pixels. 

In a series of pre-studies (online and in the lab) we collected valence, arousal and clarity ratings (‘How clearly can you tell what is depicted on the picture?’) on 9pt Likert scales from a total of 180 German-speakers (preregistration under https://osf.io/yecxk), as well as 50 Chinese-speakers. Based on this data, we excluded those black-on-white silhouette images, that received a mean clarity rating of less than 4.5 (from either language group) (n = 11). We then identified those images with a mean clarity rating higher than 4.5 but lower than 5.5 (again from either language group) (n = 44), which were assessed individually by CK and GL. In this process, another 26 images were excluded from the silhouette stimulus set, resulting in a total of 37 exclusions, which means that from the 620 original images, 583 silhouettes remained in the database. 

Based on the rating data from the remaining 583 black-on-white silhouettes, we divided the data into 3 equal parts to define cut-off points for the three valence categories (negative: 1–4.83, neutral: 4.84–6.53, positive: 6.54–8.7) and the three arousal categories (low: 2.38–4.69, mid: 4.7–5.83, high: 5.84–8.84). We pseudo-randomly assigned the 583 silhouette images to 4 stimulus lists (3 * 146 + 1 * 145), making sure that across all 4 lists, mean clarity, mean valence and mean arousal were similar, and that the number of stimuli across the 3 × 3 affective categories (valence × arousal) was comparable. Where this was not the case, CK manually reassigned stimuli to lists until the values for each criterion mentioned above were largely comparable.

2.2 Participants
We plan to recruit 800 participants representative of the US population on Prolific (https://www.prolific.co/). After successful participation in the study, participants will receive monetary compensation. Participants will be randomly assigned to a stimulus list and a rating condition (either valence or arousal).

With this sample size, there will be 400 subjects for valence ratings and also 400 for arousal ratings, each divided into 4 lists, hence around 100 ratings per image. With 100 ratings, the 95% CI of the aggregate mean rating for each image is estimated (Kauermann & Küchenhoff, 2011; Manitz, 2017) to be generally within a reasonably narrow range: within a 0.50 point range for valence and within a 0.64 point range for arousal, on the 9 point scale; based on the mean of image ratings SDs (1.28 for valence, 1.64 for arousal) from our pilot study with Austrian students.

2.3 Procedure / Data collection

### General Procedure: After presenting the informed consent and asking for demographical data, we explain the terms valance or arousal to the participants, depending on which rating condition the participant is assigned to. After the instruction, the experiment starts. Participants see a silhouette stimulus (300 x 300 px) on a grey background (hex color #808080) for 2 seconds. After this time has elapsed, the image disappears and is replaced by the rating scale (again, depending on the participant’s rating condition) – either a valence rating scale (9 pt Likert scale from very negative to very positive), or an arousal scale (9 pt Likert scale from very low to very high). Participants can enter their ratings via clicks on the scales and submit their rating by pressing a button that appears below the scales as soon as a rating value is selected, or they can skip the rating. After confirming their choice by pressing the submit button, the next image appears on screen, and so on. A total of 146 or a total of 145 images (see Material) is presented to each participant. We incorporate two attention checks:

### Attention Check 1: After all items that have to be rated have been displayed, a silhouette image is shown for which participants have to indicate, what was depicted on it. Participants, who do not answer this question correctly, will have failed Attention Check 1.

### Attention Check 2: We will measure intrarater reliability by presenting again 10 previously rated pictures at the end of the test: Five from among the most negatively rated and five from among the most positively rated images. We then correlate (Spearman’s Rho) the ratings for these with the ones previously given for the same images. 


2.4 Exclusions

### Skipped images: For each silhouette, participants have the option to skip the rating. Data from participants who skip the rating for more than 20% of the items will be excluded. 

### Attention Checks: All participants who have an intrarater reliability with a rho smaller than .7 will be excluded. Participants who fail Attention Check 1 AND have an intrarater reliability with a rho smaller than .8 will also be excluded.

3 Statistical Analysis
To assess the image ratings, we will report extensive descriptive statistics (means and standard deviations of ratings per image, their correlations, and rater reliabilities) as well as the potential effects of conventional demographic variables, largely following the paper by Kurdi et al. (2017). 

4. References

Kauermann, G., & Küchenhoff, H. (2011). Stichproben: Methoden und praktische Umsetzung mit R. Springer-Verlag. [Sample: Methods and practical implementation with R. Springer publisher.] Retrieved from https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-642-12318-4

Kurdi, B., Lozano, S., & Banaji, M. R. (2017). Introducing the open affective standardized image set (OASIS). Behavior Research Methods, 49(2), 457-470. https://doi.org/10.3758/s13428-016-0715-3

Manitz, J. (2017). Samplingbook: Survey sampling procedures. R package version 1.2.2. Retrieved from https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=samplingbook

The GIMP Development Team. (2019). GIMP. Retrieved from https://www.gimp.org

attributes.title: Specific body image aspects in eating disorders: A systematic review
attributes.description: Development of a new body image questionnaire for the eating disorders field, that will validly assess all relevant specific body image aspects in females and males.

summary.value: Specific body image aspects are shown to be important in eating disorder onset and maintenance. However, measures with one or two items are commonly employed when assessing unique body image aspects. This psychometric problem warrants a creation of an instrument that will reliably and validly capture distinct body image aspects. For this purpose, a literature review must be undertaken to investigate which body image aspects are relevant for different eating disorder diagnoses in women and men. Hence, a systematic review will be conducted to inspect these relationships and outline important drawbacks of currently used assessment tools for body image in the eating disorder field.

attributes.title: Safe management of bodies of deceased persons with suspected or confirmed COVID-19: a rapid systematic review
attributes.description: We conducted a systematic review to scope the literature and then to synthesize the available evidence addressing the safe management of bodies of deceased persons with suspected or confirmed COVID-19. This rapid systematic review was commissioned by the World Health Organization (WHO) to inform its guidance on the topic.

summary.value:
We submitted this protocol to PROSPERO prior to starting the systematic review, however due to the scoping element, it was not accepted. In the meantime, we completed the rapid systematic review within a week. We present the same protocol that was submitted to PROSPERO.

Background: Proper strategies to minimize the risk of infection in individuals handling the bodies of deceased persons infected with 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) are urgently needed. 
The objective of this study was to systematically review the literature to scope and assess the effects of specific strategies for the management of the bodies.


Review Question: What is the impact of different management of dead bodies strategies of suspected or confirmed COVID-19?

Recommendation Question: Should specific management of dead bodies of suspected or confirmed COVID-19 be used and if so which ones?

Type and method of review: systematic review, narrative synthesis

Search Strategy
We will search the following electronic databases: 
•	PubMed, EMBASE, CINAHL, and the Cochrane Library.

We will search the following Chinese electronic databases: 
•	WHO Chinese database
•	CNKI (http://new.oversea.cnki.net/index/)
•	China Biomedical Literature Service (http://www.sinomed.ac.cn/login.do)

In addition, we will search the following COVID-19 specific databases from 2019 to current date
•	Epistemonikos COVID-19 L·OVE platform (https://app.iloveevidence.com/loves/5e6fdb9669c00e4ac072701d);  
•	EPPI Centre living systematic map of the evidence (http://eppi.ioe.ac.uk/cms/Projects/DepartmentofHealthandSocialCare/Publishedreviews/COVID-19Livingsystematicmapoftheevidence/tabid/3765/Default.aspx); 
•	CORD-19 (https://www.kaggle.com/allen-institute-for-ai/CORD-19-research-challenge);
•	COVID-19 Research Database maintained by the World Health Organization (https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/global-research-on-novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov)

We will conduct a search for ongoing trials using the U.S. National Library of Medicine Register of Clinical Trials (ClinicalTrials.gov) and the WHO International Clinical Trials Registry Platform (ICTRP). We will hand-search the reference lists of the included papers. We will also review the studies included in any identified relevant systematic reviews. 

Search strategy combines relevant medical subject headings (MeSH) and keywords, which include “COVID-19”, “corona virus”, “corpse”, and “burial”. PubMed search terms are informed by https://blocks.bmi-online.nl/catalog/397. The search strategy has been drafted by Ms. Layal Hneiny and is being reviewed by two information specialists (Ms. Neera Bhatnagar and Ms. Aida Farha). Finalized search strategies will be available on March 26, 2020. For the final draft strategy see the appendix.

Content experts will search websites of governmental and organizational websites for relevant documents.

Additional search strategies to identify indirect evidence on SARS and MERS will also be constructed and peer-reviewed by information specialists. This latter search will focus on systematic reviews.

Eligibility Criteria
Population: Studies focused on deceased individuals with suspected or confirmed COVID-19 infection, SARS or MERS will be eligible for inclusion. 

Intervention: Studies addressing the safe management of dead bodies amongst the above stated population will be included. This will address the handling during different phases of the process, including: 
•	the preparation of the corpse (e.g., embalming);
•	transfer of the corpse;
•	handling during religious rituals;
•	storage of the corpse (e.g. morgues, ice rinks (one proposed strategy in Canada – just an example))
•	disposal of the corpse (burial, cremation).

Comparator: Alternative ways of management of dead bodies (to be finalized through the literature review)

Outcomes: 
•	Risk of COVID19 transmission to individuals handling the corpses and others exposed (e.g. relatives). These individuals may include nursing and medical staff in direct contact with deceased; morgue staff; transport staff; family members; crematories staff; burial staff; and religious staff.
•	Risk of transmission to members of the community
•	Acceptability by different stakeholders (family members of the deceased individual, members of the community, individuals handling the dead bodies, health authorities)
•	Unintended harms
•	Contact transmission
•	Droplet transmission
•	COVID19 infection (confirmed)
•	COVID19 probable case
•	ICU admission
•	Hospitalization
•	Death
•	(Time to) Recovery
We also will include studies that provide information about other GRADE Evidence to Decision (EtD) criteria. 

We will add other relevant outcomes identified during the literature review. The effect measures for these outcomes will depend on study design and available data.  

Study Design: No restrictions will be placed on study design. However, evidence will be prioritized by study design as follows: i) randomized controlled trials ii) non-randomized comparative studies; iii) non-comparative studies (i.e., case reports, case series); iv) qualitative studies; or v) mechanistic studies. We will also review modelling studies.

Language: We will not apply any language restrictions.

Study Selection
Search results will be imported into a single EndNote database and duplicates will be identified and removed. A PRISMA flow diagram will be used to report the flow of studies throughout the selection process. All screening will be conducted using Covidence software.

We will use the standard systematic review approach for primary studies. Specifically, all reviewers will pilot-test a title and abstract screening guide using the same 30 abstracts. Once the form is calibrated, reviewers will independently screen titles and abstracts in duplicate. Articles deemed potentially relevant by either reviewer will move on to full-text screening. All reviewers will pilot-test a full-text screening form using the same 5 full-text articles. Once the form is calibrated, two reviewers will independently screen full-texts and disagreement will be resolved by a third reviewer. We will record the primary reason for exclusion at the full-text screening stage.

Data Extraction
Two independent reviewers will extract data. Minimal data will be extracted addressing the following domains: study identifier; study design; setting; population characteristics; intervention and comparator characteristics; outcomes (quantitative if possible); source of funding and reported conflicts of interests; ethical approval; study limitations or other important comments. One reviewer will extract data for identified guidance documents and a second reviewer would verify the extracted data.

Risk of Bias Assessment
One reviewer will perform risk of bias assessments and a second reviewer will verify all assessments. We will use the Cochrane risk of bias tool (version 2) for randomized controlled trials, and the Newcastle Ottawa scale for non-randomized studies.

Synthesis
We will synthesize data in both tabular and narrative formats. We will conduct meta-analyses depending on the nature of the collected data. A single reviewer will grade the certainty of the evidence using the GRADE approach and a second reviewer will verify all assessments. If applicable, we will follow published guidance for rating the certainty in evidence in the absence
of a single estimate of effect (2, 3). Evidence will be presented using GRADE Evidence Profiles developed in the GRADEpro (www.gradepro.org) software (4, 5).

Dissemination Plan
In addition to preparing a report for WHO, we will disseminate the findings to the scientific community through publication in a peer-reviewed journal and by making it available directly to core stakeholders as reports.

Organizational Affiliation of the Review: WHO Collaborating Centre for Infectious Diseases, Research Methods and Recommendations and the Michael G. DeGroote Cochrane Canada Centre, McMaster University; and American University of Beirut

Funding Sources/Sponsors: World Health Organization, McMaster University, and American University of Beirut

Conflicts of Interest: Non declared

References

1.	Garritty C, Gartlehner G, Kamel C, King V, Nussbaumer-Streit B, Stevens A, et al. Cochrane Rapid Reviews. Interim Guidance from the Cochrane Rapid Reviews Methods Group. March 2020. 2020.
2.	Murad MH, Mustafa RA, Schunemann HJ, Sultan S, Santesso N. Rating the certainty in evidence in the absence of a single estimate of effect. Evid Based Med. 2017;22(3):85-7.
3.	Thayer KA, Schunemann HJ. Using GRADE to respond to health questions with different levels of urgency. Environ Int. 2016;92-93:585-9.
4.	Guyatt G, Oxman AD, Akl EA, Kunz R, Vist G, Brozek J, et al. GRADE guidelines: 1. Introduction-GRADE evidence profiles and summary of findings tables. J Clin Epidemiol. 2011;64(4):383-94.
5.	Guyatt GH, Thorlund K, Oxman AD, Walter SD, Patrick D, Furukawa TA, et al. GRADE guidelines: 13. Preparing summary of findings tables and evidence profiles-continuous outcomes. J Clin Epidemiol. 2013;66(2):173-83.

 
Appendix

Database: Ovid MEDLINE(R) and Epub Ahead of Print, In-Process & Other Non-Indexed Citations and Daily <1946 to March 26, 2020>
1     (pneumonia/ or pneumonia, viral/ or exp Viruses/) and (exp Disease Outbreaks/ or exp Epidemiology/ or Epidemiology.fs.) (104129)
2     coronaviridae/ or exp coronavirus/ or exp Coronavirus Infections/ or exp Betacoronavirus/ (15998)
3     (Betacoronavirus or Beta-coronavirus or Coronavirus* or COVID).mp. (14380)
4     1 or 2 or 3 (121096)
5     limit 4 to ez="20191101-20200325" (1524)
6     (("2019" adj (novel or new) adj corona*) or ("2019" adj (CoV or nCoV)) or (coronavirus adj (disease adj "2019")) or COVID19 or COVID-19 or ((Novel or New) adj Corona*) or SARS2 or SARS-CoV-2 or (SARS adj2 (coronaviridae or coronavirus)) or ((sars or Coronavirus) adj "2") or nCov or 2019ncov).mp. (4983)
7     5 or 6 (5522)
8     (Cadaver* or Corpse? or dead or remains or carcass* or death* or mortem* or cremat* or Immur* or promessi* or composting or dissolut* or grave? or tomb? or bu?ri* or bur?y* or Adipocere or ((livor or rigor or algor) adj1 mortis) or ((Postmortem or Post-mortem) adj change?) or Cruor or Autolys?s or intermit* or intermis* or interment? or commit* or entombment* or sepltur* or dispos* or deceased or (pass* adj away) or (restless adj bod*)).mp. or exp Cadaver/ (2147642)
9     7 and 8 (670)

Search Strategy
We will search the following electronic databases: 
•	PubMed, EMBASE, CINAHL, and the Cochrane Library.

We will search the following Chinese electronic databases: 
•	WHO Chinese database
•	CNKI (http://new.oversea.cnki.net/index/)
•	China Biomedical Literature Service (http://www.sinomed.ac.cn/login.do)

In addition, we will search the following COVID-19 specific databases from 2019 to current date
•	Epistemonikos COVID-19 L·OVE platform (https://app.iloveevidence.com/loves/5e6fdb9669c00e4ac072701d);  
•	EPPI Centre living systematic map of the evidence (http://eppi.ioe.ac.uk/cms/Projects/DepartmentofHealthandSocialCare/Publishedreviews/COVID-19Livingsystematicmapoftheevidence/tabid/3765/Default.aspx); 
•	CORD-19 (https://www.kaggle.com/allen-institute-for-ai/CORD-19-research-challenge);
•	COVID-19 Research Database maintained by the World Health Organization (https://www.who.int/emergencies/diseases/novel-coronavirus-2019/global-research-on-novel-coronavirus-2019-ncov)

We will conduct a search for ongoing trials using the U.S. National Library of Medicine Register of Clinical Trials (ClinicalTrials.gov) and the WHO International Clinical Trials Registry Platform (ICTRP). We will hand-search the reference lists of the included papers. We will also review the studies included in any identified relevant systematic reviews. 

Search strategy combines relevant medical subject headings (MeSH) and keywords, which include “COVID-19”, “corona virus”, “corpse”, and “burial”. PubMed search terms are informed by https://blocks.bmi-online.nl/catalog/397. The search strategy has been drafted by Ms. Layal Hneiny and is being reviewed by two information specialists (Ms. Neera Bhatnagar and Ms. Aida Farha). Finalized search strategies will be available on March 26, 2020. For the final draft strategy see the appendix.

Content experts will search websites of governmental and organizational websites for relevant documents.

Additional search strategies to identify indirect evidence on SARS and MERS will also be constructed and peer-reviewed by information specialists. This latter search will focus on systematic reviews.

Eligibility Criteria
Population: Studies focused on deceased individuals with suspected or confirmed COVID-19 infection, SARS or MERS will be eligible for inclusion. 

Intervention: Studies addressing the safe management of dead bodies amongst the above stated population will be included. This will address the handling during different phases of the process, including: 
•	the preparation of the corpse (e.g., embalming);
•	transfer of the corpse;
•	handling during religious rituals;
•	storage of the corpse (e.g. morgues, ice rinks (one proposed strategy in Canada – just an example))
•	disposal of the corpse (burial, cremation).

Comparator: Alternative ways of management of dead bodies (to be finalized through the literature review)

Outcomes: 
•	Risk of COVID19 transmission to individuals handling the corpses and others exposed (e.g. relatives). These individuals may include nursing and medical staff in direct contact with deceased; morgue staff; transport staff; family members; crematories staff; burial staff; and religious staff.
•	Risk of transmission to members of the community
•	Acceptability by different stakeholders (family members of the deceased individual, members of the community, individuals handling the dead bodies, health authorities)
•	Unintended harms
•	Contact transmission
•	Droplet transmission
•	COVID19 infection (confirmed)
•	COVID19 probable case
•	ICU admission
•	Hospitalization
•	Death
•	(Time to) Recovery
We also will include studies that provide information about other GRADE Evidence to Decision (EtD) criteria. 

We will add other relevant outcomes identified during the literature review. The effect measures for these outcomes will depend on study design and available data.  

Study Design: No restrictions will be placed on study design. However, evidence will be prioritized by study design as follows: i) randomized controlled trials ii) non-randomized comparative studies; iii) non-comparative studies (i.e., case reports, case series); iv) qualitative studies; or v) mechanistic studies. We will also review modelling studies.

Language: We will not apply any language restrictions.

Study Selection
Search results will be imported into a single EndNote database and duplicates will be identified and removed. A PRISMA flow diagram will be used to report the flow of studies throughout the selection process. All screening will be conducted using Covidence software.

We will use the standard systematic review approach for primary studies. Specifically, all reviewers will pilot-test a title and abstract screening guide using the same 30 abstracts. Once the form is calibrated, reviewers will independently screen titles and abstracts in duplicate. Articles deemed potentially relevant by either reviewer will move on to full-text screening. All reviewers will pilot-test a full-text screening form using the same 5 full-text articles. Once the form is calibrated, two reviewers will independently screen full-texts and disagreement will be resolved by a third reviewer. We will record the primary reason for exclusion at the full-text screening stage.

Data Extraction
Two independent reviewers will extract data. Minimal data will be extracted addressing the following domains: study identifier; study design; setting; population characteristics; intervention and comparator characteristics; outcomes (quantitative if possible); source of funding and reported conflicts of interests; ethical approval; study limitations or other important comments. One reviewer will extract data for identified guidance documents and a second reviewer would verify the extracted data.

Risk of Bias Assessment
One reviewer will perform risk of bias assessments and a second reviewer will verify all assessments. We will use the Cochrane risk of bias tool (version 2) for randomized controlled trials, and the Newcastle Ottawa scale for non-randomized studies.

Synthesis
We will synthesize data in both tabular and narrative formats. We will conduct meta-analyses depending on the nature of the collected data. A single reviewer will grade the certainty of the evidence using the GRADE approach and a second reviewer will verify all assessments. If applicable, we will follow published guidance for rating the certainty in evidence in the absence
of a single estimate of effect (2, 3). Evidence will be presented using GRADE Evidence Profiles developed in the GRADEpro (www.gradepro.org) software (4, 5).

Dissemination Plan
In addition to preparing a report for WHO, we will disseminate the findings to the scientific community through publication in a peer-reviewed journal and by making it available directly to core stakeholders as reports.

Organizational Affiliation of the Review: WHO Collaborating Centre for Infectious Diseases, Research Methods and Recommendations and the Michael G. DeGroote Cochrane Canada Centre, McMaster University; and American University of Beirut

Funding Sources/Sponsors: World Health Organization, McMaster University, and American University of Beirut

Conflicts of Interest: Non declared

References

1.	Garritty C, Gartlehner G, Kamel C, King V, Nussbaumer-Streit B, Stevens A, et al. Cochrane Rapid Reviews. Interim Guidance from the Cochrane Rapid Reviews Methods Group. March 2020. 2020.
2.	Murad MH, Mustafa RA, Schunemann HJ, Sultan S, Santesso N. Rating the certainty in evidence in the absence of a single estimate of effect. Evid Based Med. 2017;22(3):85-7.
3.	Thayer KA, Schunemann HJ. Using GRADE to respond to health questions with different levels of urgency. Environ Int. 2016;92-93:585-9.
4.	Guyatt G, Oxman AD, Akl EA, Kunz R, Vist G, Brozek J, et al. GRADE guidelines: 1. Introduction-GRADE evidence profiles and summary of findings tables. J Clin Epidemiol. 2011;64(4):383-94.
5.	Guyatt GH, Thorlund K, Oxman AD, Walter SD, Patrick D, Furukawa TA, et al. GRADE guidelines: 13. Preparing summary of findings tables and evidence profiles-continuous outcomes. J Clin Epidemiol. 2013;66(2):173-83.

attributes.title: Attraction to and participation in Multi-Level Marketing: Predisposing factors
attributes.description: Participants will asked a range of questions about their lifestyle, work history, psychological traits (their needs, aspirations, personality traits etc.) and their current life situation. We will also ask about participants’ attitudes towards a range of self-employment opportunities and whether they have participated in them.

q2.value:
Is there a relationship between common life goals and Multi-Level Marketing (MLM) attraction/distributorship? 

Is the relative importance of intrinsic life goals (i.e., personal growth, meaningful relationships, community contribution) to extrinsic life goals (i.e., wealth, fame, attractiveness) related to MLM attraction/distributorship?

Is there a relationship between dispositional greed and MLM attraction/distributorship?

Is there a relationship between the need for social prestige and MLM attraction/distributorship?

Is there a relationship between subjective wellbeing (i.e., life satisfaction, meaning and purpose in life, self-esteem) and MLM attraction/distributorship?

Is there a relationship between satisfaction of basic human needs (i.e., relatedness, competence, autonomy) and MLM attraction/distributorship?

Is there a relationship between desire for control (e.g., control of self, environment, and others) and MLM attraction/distributorship?

Is there a relationship between the need to belong and MLM attraction/distributorship?

Is there a relationship between participation in new-religious and/or personal development groups and MLM attraction/distributorship?

Is there a relationship between analytical-rational thinking and MLM attraction/distributorship?

Is there a relationship between intuitive-experiential thinking and MLM attraction/distributorship?

Is there a relationship between magical thinking (i.e., belief in supernatural entities, superstitions, science, thought-action fusion) and MLM attraction/distributorship?

Is there a relationship between socio-economic status and MLM attraction/distributorship?

Is there a relationship between demographics (i.e., gender, age) and MLM attraction/distributorship?

Is there a relationship between work history and MLM attraction/distributorship?

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Online questionnaire collecting quantitative data in 2 phases (phase 1: predictor variables, phase 2: outcome variables). Correlational analysis of predictor and outcome variables.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
•	We will be collecting questionnaire answers regarding psychological, motivational, social, and demographic factors. This will be quantitative in nature (i.e., numerically scored data). According to the APA Handbook of Research Methods in Psychology (Cooper & Camic, 2012) preliminary theory-building quantitative research should be overinclusive and comprehensive. This means including a wide range of potentially relevant variables that are theoretically diverse. It is our intention to conduct this initial research in this manner in order to build more specific theoretical models which can be tested in subsequent descriptive and experimental research.  
•	Details of the scales to be used in the study can be found in the document attached to this ethics proposal: “MLM Predictor and Outcome Measures”. All questions are closed-response questions. These require the participant to rate either their level of agreement or disagreement with certain statements about themselves or their lives, or how well a statement describes themselves or their life situation. Participants are not required to write their own open responses to questions.

q11.value: We will recruit a sample of 400 participants, anticipating approximately 5% dropout rate between phase 1 and phase 2 to make a total of at least 380 participants who complete the study.

q12.value:
Participants
•	380 participants were chosen to allow for accurate analysis of results with a 95% confidence level. Also this is the constraints of our budget at this time.
•	Participants will be over 18 years old and will be current Prolific crowdsourced workers. Participants will be sourced from the United States and United Kingdom as it is estimated that they will have the largest proportion of participants who have participated in an MLM in the past.
•	A 3rd-party online survey participant recruitment company, Prolific, will be used to recruit study participants. Screening out of participants less than 18 years of age takes place automatically by the Prolific platform before the survey. Only eligible participants will be able to view the survey title and description on their Prolific online platform, and can also view the time commitment (i.e., up to 20 minutes) and compensation amount (i.e., the cash amount recommended as 'good' by Prolific) for the survey.

question.value: Please see attached files for predictor and outcome variables.

•	Data will be viewed and cleaned for any poor-quality responses using best-practice methods.  
•	Descriptive data will be produced of demographics and average scores on predictor and outcome variables etc.
•	Bivariate correlations will be conducted on all appropriate continuous variables.
•	Analysis of variance will be performed with categorical variables.
•	Regression analysis will be used with variables which show significant relationships (i.e., statistically significant p < .05) between predictor and outcome variables and that may be theoretically related. This analysis will test groups of theoretically related variables to determine which variables most accurately predict the outcome variables (e.g., MLM attitudes).
•	Other assumption tests (linearity, independence etc.) will be performed to determine the accuracy of the statistical tests being conducted.

attributes.title: Mindful parenting intervention
attributes.description: A systematic review and meta-analysis of the effects of mindfulness-based parallel group interventions on psychosocial functioning of children and parents.

q1.value: Shuang Lu, Qianwen Xie, Xiaolu Dai, Renhui Lyu

q2.value: Mindfulness-based parallel group interventions have positive effects on children and parents' psychosocial functioning and overall family functioning.

q3.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The meta-analysis includes existing studies that involve mindfulness-based intervention provided to children (age 18 years or younger) and their parents/caregivers in group format during the same time period, in comparison with another non-exposed control group, or another non-mindfulness-based intervention group.

q8.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
Search strategy: Preliminary searches were conducted at Sep 5, 2019. A systematic search of 12 electronic databases are undertaken including British Nursing Index, CINAHL Plus, EMBASE, ERIC, Family & Society Studies Worldwide, MEDLINE, ProQuest Dissertations & Theses databases, PsycINFO, PubMed, Social Work Abstracts, Sociological Abstracts, The Cochrane Library, Web of Science, and Scopus. Reference lists of previous systematic reviews and included studies are hand-searched. Experts in the field are consulted. A final prepublication search will be conducted before publication. 

Four groups of search terms are used in combination and modified according to the requirements of the electronic databases: (1) Mindfulness-based (Mindful*); (2) family (parent* OR mother OR father OR caregiver* OR carer* OR family OR home); (3) children (child* OR boys OR girls OR juvenil* OR minors OR adolesc* OR preadolesc* OR pre-adolesc* OR pre-school OR preschool OR paediatric* OR pediatric* OR pubescen* OR puberty OR school* OR campus OR teen* OR young OR youth*); and (4) intervention (random* OR experiment* OR RCT OR intervention OR group OR program OR training OR therapy OR trail)

Studies are included in this meta-analysis if meeting the following criteria: (1) a mindfulness-based intervention was provided to children (age 18 years or younger) and their parents or caregivers in parallel group format; (2) experimental or quasi-experimental design was used; (3) outcome variables involved measures of psychosocial functioning of children or caregivers; (4) sufficient empirical information to calculate effect sizes was provided; and (5) the study was reported in the English language. 

Conference abstracts, secondary evidence or case reports are excluded.

All records are exported into EndNote software. Two investigators independently screen titles and abstracts for eligibility, and two investigators independently assess full texts of potentially-relevant studies. Differences are resolved by discussing with a third investigator. Information on participant and study characteristics is independently extracted by two investigators by using a pre-piloted, standardized coding scheme.

q11.value: All records that meet the inclusion criteria will be incorporated into the current study. All available post-intervention and follow-up time points will be extracted and analyzed.

question.value:
Main outcomes: 
Parenting: including levels of parenting stress, mindful parenting, parenting effectiveness, changes in parenting style, and other parenting-related outcomes. Measurements include: Interpersonal Mindfulness in Parenting (IMP) questionnaire, Parenting Stress Index (PSI), the Parenting Scale (PS), Affective/Interaction Quality, and so forth.

Additional outcomes:
Parent mental health related: such as Depress, Anxiety, and Stress Scale (DASS), and Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ).
Child mental health and functioning related: such as child behavioral problems (Child Behavior Checklist, CBCL), executive function (The Behavior Rating Inventory of Executive Function, BRIEF), inattention (ADHD Rating Scale, ARS), anxiety and depression (Multidimensional Anxiety Scale for Children, MASC; Child Depression Inventory, CDI), and quality of life (Pediatric Quality of Life, PedsQL).
Level of Mindfulness: such as those measured by Child and Adolescent Mindfulness Measure (CAMM), Mindful Attention Awareness Scale (MAAS), and Five Facet Mindfulness Questionnaire (FFMQ).

Calculations for the meta-analysis will be performed using the Comprehensive Meta-Analysis software. For each intervention, we will compute an effect size as a standardized mean difference (SMD) between the mean of a mindfulness-based intervention group and a control group at posttest using Cohen’s d. We will convert each study-level treatment effect to a SMD for calculating an overall effect size. The precisions of effect sizes will be addressed by the 95% CI. The Q statistic will be used to test the homogeneity across studies and significant Qs imply heterogeneity. I2 (I2) will be used to measure the degree of inconsistency between studies.

q20.value: Two investigators will independently assess the methodological quality of each study. The Newcastle-Ottawa Scale (NOS) will be used to evaluate the quality of quantitative studies and the Critical Appraisal Skills Programme (CASP) Quality Appraisal Checklist will be used to evaluate the quality of qualitative studies.

q21.value: Where effect size information (or information to allow the calculation of this statistic) is missing, the authors will be contacted. If authors are unable to provide this data, the original study will be excluded from the analysis and recorded in accordance with PRISMA guidelines.

q22.value:
Subgroup analyses will be conducted if data availability allows. The subgroups may include: study design (randomized/non-randomized trial); participant gender (male/female).
Interaction between groups will be tested.
